Article Title: Inside Chinaâ€™s gray zone activities: How Beijing is salami slicing its way to influence
Article Text:
taoguang yanghui

'China Will Not Be Allowed To Be A Hegemon': Expert On US' Asia Strategy, India's Defence Posture

The salami slicing concept

Ambiguity in international law

Slow dispute-resolution mechanisms

Reluctance among states to escalate

The South China Sea: Why this geography matters

The nine-dash line and the problem of overlapping claims

Scarborough Shoal: The turning point

From reefs to runways: Incremental militarisation

International law enters â€“ and is sidelined

Gray zone pressure as a permanent condition

Maritime militias and the blurring of war and peace

Salami slicing beyond the South China Sea

Military signalling:

Cyber operations:

Economic coercion:

Legal instruments:

Space and infrastructure:

Undersea cables: the next gray zone frontier

Influence without invasion

The cumulative effect

â€œHide your strength and bide your time,â€ Deng Xiaoping, the transformative Chinese premier, once advised â€“ a maxim that became shorthand for Chinaâ€™s post-Cold War foreign policy. It urged patience, strategic restraint and the quiet accumulation of national power, while avoiding confrontations that could derail domestic development. The idea â€”â€” shaped Beijingâ€™s external posture for decades.For decades, Beijing followed that script closely.Under President Xi Jinping , that restraint has eroded. China today operates with a dual posture: overt where it can, ambiguous where it must. The shift is visible not only in rhetoric but in a pattern of calibrated actions â€“ military, economic, legal and technological â€“ that collectively alter realities on the ground without triggering open conflict.The change is not always announced through declarations or formal doctrine. Instead, it is visible in actions that appear isolated when viewed individually, but form a coherent strategy when taken together.This strategy operates in what analysts call the â€œgray zoneâ€: the space between peace and war, where states pursue coercive objectives without crossing thresholds that would trigger direct military retaliation. And at the heart of Chinaâ€™s gray zone behaviour lies a method that strategists have come to describe as salami slicing.Do we not have checks and balances? Maybe international rules based order?International law, on paper, has been unambiguous. Yet Beijingâ€™s response to adverse rulings has been equally consistent. When the International Court of Justice under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) ruled in July 2016 that Chinaâ€™s sweeping claims in the South China Sea had no legal basis, Beijing dismissed the verdict as â€œnull and voidâ€ and â€œdevoid of any binding forceâ€ and continued its activities unabated. The episode stressed again on a recurring dilemma for the international system: rules exist, but enforcement against a determined major power remains elusive.This tension â€“ between legal clarity and strategic ambiguity â€“ lies at the heart of Chinaâ€™s covert strategy.Salami slicing is not a Chinese term, or a formal doctrine codified in military manuals, nor is it confined to military affairs. The concept originated in Cold War Europe, where it described how political power could be consolidated gradually â€“ slice by slice â€“ without provoking decisive resistance.It refers to the pursuit of strategic objectives through a series of small, calibrated steps, each designed to fall below the threshold that would trigger military retaliation or unified international response. No single move is decisive, but together they transform the strategic landscape.According to the US National Intelligence Council, gray zone activities involve â€œcoercive or subversive actions to achieve objectives at the expense of others in contravention of, or in the absence of, international norms,â€ while remaining below the threshold of armed conflict â€“ a definition cited by the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission.Applied to China, salami slicing thrives on ambiguity. It exploits the hesitation of rivals, the slow machinery of international law, and the difficulty of mobilising collective responses to actions that appear non-violent, technical or civilian in nature. Over time, it creates new facts on the ground â€“ or on the water â€“ that become difficult to reverse.Chinaâ€™s gray zone activities span military, economic, cyber, legal, informational and space domains, and are deliberately structured to exploit:Nowhere has this approach been more systematically applied than in the South China Sea â€“ but it does not end there.The South China Sea is not merely a regional waterway. It is one of the worldâ€™s most economically and strategically consequential maritime corridors, linking Northeast Asia with the Indian Ocean and Europe and carrying energy supplies, manufactured goods and raw materials essential to the global economy.According to the China Power Project at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), roughly one-third of global maritime trade passes through the South China Sea every year. Chinaâ€™s dependence on this maritime corridor is particularly high.CSIS data shows that in 2016, more than 64% of Chinaâ€™s maritime trade â€“ valued at approximately $874 billion â€“ transited these waters. Control over the sea, therefore, carries consequences far beyond geography; it shapes economic security, supply chains and strategic leverage, a reality that underpins Beijingâ€™s long-term approach.It is against this backdrop that Chinaâ€™s expansive maritime claims must be understood.China claims â€œhistoric rightsâ€ over most of the South China Sea based on a map first published in 1947, marked by a series of dashes enclosing nearly the entire basin. This so-called nine-dash line overlaps with the exclusive economic zones (EEZs) of several Southeast Asian states, including the Philippines and Vietnam.Under the UNCLOS, coastal states are entitled to EEZs extending up to 200 nautical miles from their shores, granting them rights over resources such as fisheries and hydrocarbons. Many Southeast Asian economies rely heavily on access to these zones.Chinaâ€™s claims cut across this legal framework â€“ but instead of enforcing them through direct military confrontation, Beijing has pursued control through incremental occupation and sustained presence.Rather than enforcing its position through direct confrontation, China has pursued control incrementally. The process that began in the 1970s with the seizure of the Paracel Islands, follows till today.The strategy became unmistakable in 2012, during a standoff at Scarborough Shoal, a small but strategically located reef just 120 nautical miles west of the Philippine island of Luzon.The confrontation began when Philippine authorities attempted to arrest Chinese fishermen operating within Manilaâ€™s EEZ. What followed was not a naval battle, but a prolonged game of manoeuvre. Chinese coast guard vessels, naval units and maritime militia ships blocked access to the shoal, eventually establishing de facto control.There was no formal declaration, no transfer ceremony, no shots fired. Philippine vessels withdrew. Chinese ships stayed.Multiple analysts have widely cited Scarborough Shoal as a textbook example of salami slicing: a gradual, attritional takeover that altered the status quo without triggering a military response.Scarborough was not an isolated case. It was part of a longer trajectory.China began asserting control over features in the South China Sea as early as the 1970s, when it took the Paracel Islands from Vietnam. In 1995, it occupied Mischief Reef, a submerged feature claimed by the Philippines and Vietnam. In 2012, Scarborough followed.According to the Wall Street Journal, from 2013 to 2016, Beijing escalated its approach by undertaking a massive land-reclamation programme across the Spratly Islands. Submerged reefs such as Mischief Reef and Subi Reef were transformed into artificial islands capable of hosting airstrips, deep-water ports, radar installations and military garrisons.In September 2015, President Xi Jinping stated publicly that â€œWe are committed to maintaining peace and stability in the South China Sea, and China does not intend to pursue militarizationâ€ of the South China Sea.US officials later said satellite imagery showed the deployment of missile systems, aircraft hangars, jamming equipment and advanced sensors on several of these features, contradicting that assurance, reported WSJ.By the mid-2010s, China had established 27 outposts across disputed areas â€“ 20 in the Paracels and seven in the Spratlys â€“ significantly expanding its ability to project power and monitor activity across the sea.The Philippines sought to challenge Chinaâ€™s actions through legal means. In July 2016, the International Court of Justice under UNCLOS ruled overwhelmingly in Manilaâ€™s favour.The tribunal found that Chinaâ€™s historic rights claims under the nine-dash line had no legal basis, and that several features occupied by China lay within the Philippinesâ€™ EEZ and could not generate maritime entitlements of their own.China rejected the ruling outright, calling it â€œnull and voidâ€ and refusing to participate in the proceedings. It did not vacate any occupied features, nor did it scale back its activities.The episode exposed a structural weakness in the international rules-based order: international courts can clarify law, but they lack enforcement mechanisms when major powers choose non-compliance. Scarborough Shoal remains under Chinese control. The facts on the water did not change.Since the ruling, China has only intensified gray zone maritime pressure rather than reducing it.According to the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission, Chinese coast guard and affiliated vessels over the years even in 2025 repeatedly harassed Philippine operations near contested features such as Second Thomas Shoal, where a small contingent of Filipino personnel remains stationed on a grounded naval vessel.These encounters have involved water cannons, deliberate blocking manoeuvres and collisions. At least one Filipino sailor was seriously injured during such clashes, according to a CNN report.Analysts say the objective is not immediate eviction, but gradual exhaustion â€“ making continued presence increasingly costly and risky without provoking outright conflict. Helena Legarda, a maritime analyst, has described the approach as one that seeks to â€œmake occupancy untenable over time.â€Chinaâ€™s maritime posture increasingly relies on a layered force structure that blurs civilian and military roles.A key element of Chinaâ€™s strategy is the use of the country's maritime militia â€“ ostensibly civilian fishing fleets organised and directed by state authorities â€“ routinely shadow foreign vessels, block access to contested features and engage in aggressive manoeuvres.Operating alongside the coast guard and navy, these vessels intimidate foreign fishermen, shadow naval patrols and assert presence in disputed waters. Their civilian appearance complicates response options for rival states, which risk escalation if they use force.This blending of civilian and military roles allows China to apply pressure while maintaining plausible deniability â€“ a hallmark of gray zone operations.At the Second Thomas Shoal, Chinese coast guard vessels have repeatedly obstructed resupply missions to a grounded Philippine naval ship used to assert sovereignty.This approach reflects what Chinese strategists have termed â€œcabbage tacticsâ€ â€“ surrounding contested features with multiple layers of vessels to isolate them gradually.While the South China Sea offers the clearest illustration, salami slicing is not confined to maritime disputes.The US Commission documents a broad pattern of gray zone activities across domains:The Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army Air Force conducted thousands of incursions into Taiwanâ€™s air defence identification zone (ADIZ) in 2024, averaging nearly three per day â€“ a sustained pressure campaign short of invasion.Chinese coast guard vessels spent a record number of days operating near disputed islands administered by Japan, regularly entering territorial waters.Taiwanâ€™s National Security Bureau reported an average of 2.4 million cyberattacks per day against government networks in 2024, attributing most to Chinaâ€™s cyber forces. US officials have warned that Chinese advanced persistent threat groups have infiltrated critical infrastructure networks to pre-position for potential disruptions.Beijing has timed trade investigations and regulatory actions around political events, restricted exports of critical minerals since late 2023, and selectively removed tariffs to reward diplomatic alignment â€“ using market access as leverage.China has expanded the authority of its coast guard to detain vessels and personnel in waters it claims, providing a domestic legal veneer to contested actions. It has also launched antimonopoly investigations into foreign firms amid broader trade disputes.In 2024 and 2025, China conducted a series of proximity operations in space, demonstrating capabilities to interfere with or disable other satellites. A Chinese satellite firm with reported links to the PLA allegedly provided imagery to non-state actors involved in Red Sea attacks, according to US officials.One of the least visible â€” yet most consequential â€” arenas of gray zone competition lies beneath the ocean surface.Undersea cables carry an estimated 95% of global internet traffic, underpinning financial transactions, military communications and government services. According to the US-China Review Commission, Chinese research institutions affiliated with the PLA have studied cable-cutting techniques for more than a decade, securing patents for deep-sea severing technologies.In February 2025, Chinese scientists linked to the China Ship Scientific Research Center unveiled a design for an electric cutting device capable of severing armoured cables at depths exceeding 13,000 feet.Since 2023, multiple incidents involving Chinese-owned vessels have damaged undersea cables near Taiwan and in the Baltic Sea.In November 2024, a Chinese vessel dragged its anchor for more than 100 miles, severing cables connecting Sweden-Lithuania and Germany-Finland. European investigators later indicated suspected coordination with Russian intelligence.China has also delayed repairs by requiring permits for cable repair ships operating in waters it claims, prolonging outages and creating economic disruption. US officials have warned that Chinese repair vessels could also be used for espionage, exploiting a shortage of alternative repair capacity in the Asia-Pacific.Taken together, these activities demonstrate not only capability development but operational rehearsal for future contingencies.Beyond territory, China has pursued incremental influence through infrastructure finance, technology standards and institutional positioning.Building on the Belt and Road Initiative, Beijingâ€™s Global Security Initiative has expanded security cooperation with low- and middle-income countries, frequently offering surveillance and policing systems supplied by firms such as Huawei.According to US assessments, these systems are often embedded in critical infrastructure, raising concerns about data access and service disruption during geopolitical crises.China has also sought greater representation in international standard-setting bodies, shaping technical norms in ways that favour its industrial and governance models. These moves rarely provoke immediate opposition but, over time, alter decision-making terrain.Each individual action â€“ a patrol, a regulation, a cyber intrusion, a reef turned island â€“ may appear manageable in isolation. None of these actions alone constitutes war. None demands immediate escalation. That is precisely the point. The strategic impact emerges only in aggregation.This is the essence of salami slicing: incremental steps that avoid red lines, exploit hesitation, and create new facts on the ground. By the time responses coalesce, the baseline has shifted.As the 2016 UNCLOS ruling demonstrated, law can clarify rights, but it cannot by itself reverse realities established through years of calibrated action.Chinaâ€™s gray zone strategy operates on that premise â€“ that influence can be accumulated without war, and that patience, once urged by Deng Xiaoping, can be replaced by persistence under ambiguity.For the international system, the challenge remains unresolved: how to respond to change that is slow, deliberate and legally contested â€“ but strategically decisive.
Article Summary: China operates with a dual posture: overt where it can, ambiguous where it must. It exploits the hesitation of rivals, the slow machinery of international law, and the difficulty of mobilising collective responses to actions that appear non-violent, technical or civilian in nature.

Article Title: Who was Saif al-Islam Gaddafi? Son of late Libya dictator Moammar Gaddafi killed in his home
Article Text:
Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, once seen as Libya's Western-friendly reformer and heir apparent, has been killed in a direct confrontation after gunmen stormed his home. He played a key role in his father's regime, later becoming a divisive figure during the 2011 uprising. After years of detention and a death sentence, he resurfaced seeking the presidency, a bid that ultimately failed.

The acceptable face of Gaddafi-era Libya

2011 uprising and the turn to force

Capture, detention and legal cases

Return from the shadows and election bid

Symbolic weight, contested legacy





Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, once viewed as the Western-friendly face of Libya and heir apparent to longtime ruler Muammar Gaddafi, was killed in a â€œdirect confrontationâ€ after gunmen broke into his home, his office said on Tuesday. No further details of the incident were disclosed.Despite holding no official government post, Saif al-Islam was for years considered one of the most powerful figures in Libya, shaping policy and serving as a key interlocutor with Western governments during his fatherâ€™s four-decade rule.Educated at the London School of Economics and fluent in English, Saif al-Islam cultivated close ties with Western capitals and was widely seen as a reformist figure within the Libyan system.He played a central role in Libyaâ€™s decision to abandon its weapons of mass destruction programme and negotiated compensation for families of victims of the 1988 Pan Am Flight 103 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland.He frequently called for a constitution, political reform and respect for human rights, positioning himself as the figure who could reintegrate Libya into the international community after years of sanctions and isolation.That image collapsed when the 2011 uprising against Muammar Gaddafi erupted. Saif al-Islam publicly sided with his father and became one of the architects of the regimeâ€™s violent response to the revolt, referring to rebels as â€œratsâ€.â€œWe fight here in Libya, we die here in Libya,â€ he told Reuters at the time. He warned that â€œrivers of bloodâ€ would flow and said the government would fight â€œto the last man and woman and bulletâ€.In a televised address, he cautioned: â€œAll of Libya will be destroyed. We will need 40 years to reach an agreement on how to run the country, because today, everyone will want to be president, or emir, and everybody will want to run the country.â€After Tripoli fell to rebels, Saif al-Islam attempted to flee to neighbouring Niger disguised as a Bedouin tribesman. He was captured by the Abu Bakr al-Sadiq Brigade militia and taken to the western town of Zintan, about a month after his father was killed by rebels.â€œIâ€™m staying here. Theyâ€™ll empty their guns into me the second I go out there,â€ he said in comments captured on an audio recording during his capture, according to Reuters.He spent about six years in detention in Zintan. Human Rights Watch said he did not allege physical abuse, though concerns were raised over prolonged solitary confinement. He said he was isolated and did not receive visitors, though he had access to television and books.In 2015, a Tripoli court sentenced him to death by firing squad for war crimes. The International Criminal Court also issued an arrest warrant against him for â€œmurder and persecutionâ€.Released in 2017 under an amnesty law, Saif al-Islam remained largely underground for years to avoid assassination, according to Libyan analyst Mustafa Fetouri. From 2016, he was allowed limited contact with people inside and outside Libya.In 2021, wearing traditional Libyan attire, he resurfaced publicly to file his candidacy for Libyaâ€™s planned presidential elections, seeking to draw on nostalgia for stability under his fatherâ€™s rule.His candidacy proved deeply divisive. He was disqualified due to his conviction, and efforts to appeal were blocked by armed groups. The dispute became a major factor in the collapse of the election process and Libyaâ€™s return to political stalemate.â€œIâ€™ve been away from the Libyan people for 10 years,â€ he told The New York Times Magazine in 2021. â€œYou need to come back slowly, slowly. Like a striptease. You need to play with their minds a little.â€Analysts say Saif al-Islam retained symbolic importance despite limited public engagement.â€œAfter Saif al-Islam was freed a few years ago, he proved incapable of delivering speeches or producing public statements through the press or social media,â€ Jalel Harchaoui of the Royal United Services Institute told Reuters. â€œYet his symbolic significance remained substantial.â€â€œNow that he has been slain, most pro-Gaddafi factions will experience both diminished morale and anger,â€ Harchaoui said, adding that one major obstacle to holding elections in Libya had been removed.
Article Summary: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi was killed in a â€˜direct confrontationâ€™ after gunmen broke into his home. He played a key role in his father's regime, later becoming a divisive figure during the 2011 uprising. After years of detention and a death sentence, he resurfaced seeking the presidency.

Pakistan has been invited to participate in upcoming talks between Iran and the United States aimed at easing tensions between the two countries, slated to take place on Friday in Turkey.â€œPakistan has received the invitation for the upcoming talks between Iran and the United States,â€ Pakistan foreign office spokesperson Tahir Andrabi said while responding to a query, reported Dawn.Pakistan's deputy prime minister and foreign minister Ishaq Dar is expected to take part in the meeting, the daily reported citing a diplomatic source, adding that â€œIslamabadâ€™s participation was seen as significant.â€An Arab official told AFP on condition of anonymity that the meeting is likely to be held in Turkiye on Friday. Article Title: US-Russia nuclear treaty nears expiry, Kremlin warns of 'dangerous' moment: Why New START matters for global security
Article Text:
Putin Aide Medvedev Shoots APOCALYPSE Warning As Last US-Russia Nuclear Treaty Nears Expiry | Watch

What is the US-Russia nuclear treaty and why it matters



The Kremlin on Tuesday warned that the world was heading into a â€œdangerousâ€ phase as the last remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the United States and Russia is set to expire this week, potentially leaving the two largest nuclear powers without any formal limits on their arsenals.The treaty, known as New START, is due to expire on Thursday. It is the final surviving agreement from a series of Cold War-era arms control deals that once governed nuclear competition between Washington and Moscow.â€œIn just a few days, the world will be in a more dangerous position than it has ever been before,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told journalists, including AFP, during a daily briefing.The Kremlin said it had proposed a one-year extension of the treaty but had received no formal response from Washington. â€œWe still haven't received a response from the Americans to this initiative,â€ Peskov said.If the treaty lapses without replacement or extension, the United States and Russia would, for the first time in decades, be without any binding framework to limit or verify their strategic nuclear weapons. Moscow warned this would remove the only remaining mechanism to control the worldâ€™s two largest nuclear arsenals.US President Donald Trump, who oversaw the withdrawal of the United States from several international agreements, said in September that extending New START â€œsounds like a good idea,â€ but no concrete steps have followed.The treaty was signed in 2010 by then Russian President Dmitry Medvedev and US President Barack Obama, and came into force the following year. It included provisions for on-site inspections and data exchanges to ensure compliance.However, Russia suspended inspections during the COVID-19 pandemic, and broader talks on extending or replacing the treaty stalled as relations deteriorated following the war in Ukraine. Moscow has accused Washington of obstructing inspection missions on US territory.In 2023, Russia announced it was freezing its participation in New START, although it said it would continue to voluntarily adhere to the numerical limits set by the treaty.The warning comes amid rising military signalling on both sides. Moscow last year tested new nuclear-capable delivery systems without warheads, while Trump said he had ordered two US nuclear submarines to move closer to Russia.New START is the last remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the United States and Russia and is widely seen as a cornerstone of global strategic stability.Under the agreement, both countries are limited to 1,550 deployed strategic nuclear warheads each. The treaty also caps deployed intercontinental ballistic missiles, submarine-launched ballistic missiles and heavy bombers at 700, with an additional limit of 800 launchers. These weapons are designed to strike an adversaryâ€™s key political, military and industrial targets in the event of a nuclear conflict.A central feature of New START is its verification regime, which allows for on-site inspections, notifications and data sharing to reduce the risk of miscalculation. While inspections have been halted since the pandemic and Russiaâ€™s suspension of participation, neither side has formally accused the other of breaching the warhead limits.The treaty was extended once in 2021, shortly after Trumpâ€™s successor took office, as the agreement allows only a single extension. With that option exhausted, any further continuation would require a new deal or informal political understanding.Analysts warn that the expiry of New START would end more than five decades of formal nuclear arms control between Washington and Moscow. Previous agreements, including the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty and the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty, have already collapsed.Without a replacement framework, both sides would be free to expand their nuclear arsenals, though experts say large-scale increases would take time due to technical and logistical constraints. Over the longer term, the absence of limits and transparency could fuel a renewed arms race driven by worst-case assumptions.Efforts to negotiate a successor treaty face major hurdles. Trump has said he wants a broader agreement that includes China, an idea Beijing has rejected, arguing its arsenal is far smaller. Russia has countered that the nuclear forces of Britain and France should also be included, a proposal those countries oppose.With New START nearing expiration and no clear diplomatic breakthrough in sight, the future of US-Russia nuclear arms control remains uncertain, raising concerns about rising nuclear risks at a time of heightened global tensions.
Article Summary: New START is the last remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the United States and Russia. It is the final surviving agreement from a series of Cold War-era arms control deals that once governed nuclear competition between Washington and Moscow. Moscow warned this would remove the only remaining mechanism to control the worldâ€™s two largest nuclear arsenals.

Article Title: Canadian nurse Lovedip Sandhu pleads guilty to $55,000 drug fraud, admits addiction as empty syringes, vials found at Quebec home
Article Text: A former nurse has pleaded guilty to fraud and drug possession after admitting to defrauding a Quebec medical clinic of more than $55,000 to obtain opioid medications.Lovedip Sandhu, a 35-year-old Canadian national and resident of Pierrefonds, entered her guilty plea in mid-January to charges of fraud over $5,000 and simple possession of narcotics. The offences stem from her work at a private plastic surgery clinic in Montreal in 2021, reports French-Canadian newspaper La Presse.Sandhu was employed at Clinique K, a plastic surgery clinic in Westmount, where she worked as a nursing assistant. Her duties included preparing patients for surgery, organising medication orders, and dealing with pharmaceutical companies on behalf of the clinic.Between March and September 2021, prosecutors say Sandhu carried out 75 fraudulent transactions without her employerâ€™s knowledge. She forged the signature of the clinicâ€™s owner, Dr Karl Schwarz, to place orders for opiates. She later collected the drugs from pharmacies and paid for them using the clinicâ€™s credit cards.Through the scheme, Sandhu obtained 3,778 one-millilitre vials of sufentanil and 2,138 one-millilitre vials of hydromorphone.At the time of the offences, Sandhu was a registered member of the Quebec Order of Nurses and Nursing Assistants.She is no longer part of the professional body, having been expelled in 2022.Following her arrest in September 2021, Sandhu told police she had developed an addiction earlier that year due to health issues. She admitted initially taking medication from the clinicâ€™s supply before her use increased.Police searches uncovered empty syringes and vials, several boxes of medication, and $11,000 in cash at her homes. Sentencing submissions in the case have been postponed until June.

Loretto Hospital gave shots to people who were not yet eligible, including workers at Trump Tower and members of an Oak Forest church.According to reporting by Block Club Chicago, Ahmed came to US as a child from Pakistan.Court documents allege that he obtained personal information of around 150,000 patients at Loretto Hospital and used it to submit fraudulent claims to the federal government.Ahmed and two others, Heather Bergdahl and Sameer Suhail, were charged in 2024 with embezzling over $15 million from the hospital by submitting fake invoices and false payment requests.Last year, Ahmed and three others were accused of filing nearly $900 million in fake claims for Covid-19 testing materials, with about $293 million paid out. The other people charged are Mohamed Sirajudeen, Mahmood Sami Khan, and Suhaib Ahmad Chaudhry. Prosecutors say Sirajudeen is expected to plead guilty before theA hearing for the case is set for February 13, 2026. Prosecutors said that if Ahmed is not extradited, they will adjust the evidence for the defendants who are on trial.
Article Summary: Pakistan-born Anosh Ahmed, a former executive at Loretto Hospital in Chicago, has been arrested in Serbia after fleeing the United States. US prosecutors have confirmed that they intend to seek his extradition. Ahmed resigned in March 2021 after controversies during the Covid-19 pandemic involving improper vaccination incidents.

Article Title: Texas journalist 'exposes' Indian recruiters behind 'H-1B only' job ads on LinkedIn: 'When I call the numbers...'
Article Text: Texas journalist Sara Gonzales, who knocked on the doors of a few H-1B addresses in Texas, exposing a 'major scam' in the state, has now targeted Indian recruiters offering 'H-1B only' jobs at various US locations on LinkedIn. Gonzales said she visited the websites of the companies and found a common pattern: most of the contact numbers given on the sites do not work, the companies have their offices in India; they have unpolished/ wrong choice of English words on their sites; and they rent out virtual remote coworking space so that they can have an address but no one is there."Let me be clear to the fraudsters. We are not done. Keep watching. It may be you we are exposing very shortly," Gonzales said. The journalist added that it was her expose that prompted Texas Governor Greg Abbott to announce a freeze on H-1B hiring ban in state agencies. Also, Texas AG Ken Paxton announced an investigation into three private companies.Gonzales said she researched for an evening and found an avalanche of information about Indian recruiters posting 'H-1B only' ads on LinkedIn. Revealing their names and the companies they have been hiring for, Gonzales read out one advertisement that was offering jobs only for H-4s, who are dependents of H-1Bs."This is the whole scheme. You get in, you get to bring your whole family, you bring your children. Then your children need to be taught by another H-1B. And that H-1B brings their family in, and they bring their children. It is a recurring, never-ending cycle," Gonzales said adding that H-1B is supposed to be used only when American talent is not found for some very niche skills.The IT consulting firms are double-dipping as they don't pay what they get from the companies to the H-1Bs they hire, the journalist alleged. "If you are a Green Card holder, if you did immigrate to this country, if you came to this country as a foreign national and paid your dues, and you are now a Green Card holder, you still do not need to apply. We don't want you. We want the non-immigrant visas. What a slap in the face," Gonzales said.
Article Summary: Texas journalist Sara Gonzales has targeted Indian recruiters offering 'H-1B only' jobs at various US locations on LinkedIn. Gonzales said she visited the websites of the companies and found a common pattern: most of the contact numbers given on the sites do not work, the companies have their offices in India and they rent out virtual remote coworking space.

Article Title: Empty offices, no hospital equipment: Kazakhstan, Pakistan nationals charged in massive $1 billion medicare fraud across US
Article Text:
First case

Federal prosecutors in Chicago have charged several foreign nationals with running vast Medicare and health insurance fraud schemes that allegedly siphoned more than $1 billion from US government programmes and private insurers by billing for medical equipment and tests that were never provided.Court filings describe shell companies, empty offices and false claims for items such as glucose monitors, catheters and diagnostic tests. Investigators say the schemes relied on stolen patient data and exploited weaknesses in the Medicare system.In the first case, prosecutors charged Anuar Abdrakhmanov, a citizen of Kazakhstan, with conspiracy to launder money linked to Medicare fraud. Court documents say he took over a legitimate medical supply company in Kentucky, Priority One Medical Equipment, and used it to submit about $666 million in false Medicare claims between March and August 2024. Abdrakhmanov entered the United States on a summer work visa in May 2023 that expired four months later but stayed in the country. He became a member and manager of Priority One in April 2024 after buying the company from its previous owner. During this period, Medicare received around 250 complaints from patients who said they never received the equipment they were billed for. Investigators also found that six Medicare beneficiaries in Illinois neither requested nor received glucose monitors or catheters and did not have diabetes.When authorities visited Priority Oneâ€™s Kentucky office in July 2024, it was empty and not operating. Workers told investigators their only task was to collect mail and send photos of it via the encrypted app Telegram to a supervisor they had never met. Financial records show checks were sent by FedEx to Chicago suburbs, including one $1 million cheque that was misplaced and later recovered, earning the worker a $2,000 bonus. While Medicare suspended payments, Medigap insurers paid at least $450,000. Prosecutors say Abdrakhmanov then wired about $182,000 to Hong Kong and tried to send over $200,000 to other foreign accounts.A second case involves another Kazakhstan national, Tair Smagul, who lived in Chicago and is accused of laundering money tied to a separate Medicare fraud scheme. Prosecutors allege Smagul controlled Connecticut-based Medical Home Care Inc and took part in a nationwide operation that billed nearly $953 million for catheters that were often unnecessary or never delivered.Medicare reportedly got over 27,000 complaints about Medical Home Care. Patients interviewed by investigators said they never received any supplies, and doctors listed as having prescribed the equipment said they never approved itIn a third case, prosecutors charged Pakistani nationals Burhan Mirza and Kashif Iqbal with orchestrating a $10 million fraud involving diagnostic tests and medical equipment. Mirza allegedly ran a business in Pakistan, while Iqbal lived in Texas and worked with US-based accomplices to submit false claims using stolen patient information. Prosecutors say millions were routed through shell companies with fabricated names. Iqbal is also accused of lying to federal investigators about his role.

Investigators say the schemes relied on stolen patient data and exploited weaknesses in the Medicare system.

Article Title: America invited us in: Indian-origin tech leader who funded over 100 startups says he's worried about future

The front offices in America and the back offices in India helped both countries and if this trend is reversed now, both will be affected."India just became the fourth-largest economy in the world, and it will likely become the third-largest by 2030. Itâ€™s imperative that the worldâ€™s oldest democracy (America) and the worldâ€™s largest democracy (India) work together, not only to stay ahead of China on the technological front lines but to stem the rise of authoritarianism globally," the investor added.

Article Title: Random Musing: Did 'The Matrix' foreshadow Jeffrey Epstein?
Article Text:
Michael Wolff Throws The Gauntlet: Trump Vs Author In Epstein Showdown

The Merovingian Restaurant Scene.

Neo vs Merovingian | The Matrix Reloaded [IMAX]

Merovingian Resurrections





The year 1999 was a standout year for Hollywood movies. Perhaps the imminent threat of Y2K really released peopleâ€™s creative juices. In that year, we got the Star Wars prequel classic The Phantom Menace, the misunderstood manifesto of machismo Fight Club, the creepy precursor to Kevin Spaceyâ€™s behaviour in American Beauty, the kid who could see dead people in The Sixth Sense, the goofy coming-of-age movie American Pie, and romantic escapades in Notting Hill.But if there is one movie which became part of the cultural lexicon, foreshadowing how all humans would become plugged into the machines and conned by algorithms for a deus ex machina, then it was The Matrix.The Matrix and its sequels (barring the unwatchable The Matrix Resurrections), as a sci-fi franchise, has had a cultural impact hitherto unseen.Many of the terms in The Matrix have become part of our lexicon. Red pill and blue pill became the choice between a hard truth and a comfortable illusion. Waking up meant realising we are surrounded by an illusion. It was the movie that made philosophy cool, that mainstreamed nerd culture, where we suddenly learned how Platoâ€™s man in a cave could make a pretty great plot point because the action was that good.The Matrix also had a host of memorable characters like Neo, a messianic Jesus-like figure who would ultimately sacrifice himself like Jesus, but not before showing off some cool kung fu moves.Then thereâ€™s Trinity, named after the Holy Trinity, whose faith in Neo makes him the One. Morpheus, named after the Greek god of dreams, is the one who wakes people up from their slumber and tells them walk the path.Even the side characters are super cool.Take the Merovingian, a character so suave and French that his tie knot immediately became a fashion statement and he could Emmaneul Macron fashion tips.Suave, smug, impeccably dressed, and aggressively French, the Merovingian was an old program who survived by running a black-market empire inside the Matrix. His tie knot alone became a fashion statement. Named after the Frankish dynasty that once ruled large parts of Europe and later spawned myths about being descendants of Jesus Christ and Mary Magdalene, the Merovingianâ€™s symbolism was as in your face as a Truth Social post by the Orange one. He existed in the shadows of power, ancient, connected, and convinced of his own immorality.For those who donâ€™t remember, the Merovingian (also called the Frenchman) is an old program (or operating system) that resides in the Matrix and operates a smuggling ring providing a haven for exiled programs. He is a trafficker of information, loves living the high life, has a partner who helps him run his criminal syndicate, talks with utmost smug superiority, keeps old programs like trophies, sells access to the powers-that-be, operates from private spaces as theatres of control, hides behind moral relativism as his philosophy (â€œItâ€™s all a game, itâ€™s always been a gameâ€), and pretends he has all the answers.When Morpheus asks him in the restaurant scene, â€œDo you know why we are here?â€, he replies without batting an eyelid: â€œI am a trafficker of information, I know everything I can. The question is, do you know why you are here?â€And of course, he loves controlling programs around him, putting a tiny bit of code in a womanâ€™s dessert as a means to control her.Not to mention that he believes heâ€™s infallible, telling Neo during a fight: â€œBoy, I have survived your predecessors, and mark my words, I will survive you.â€Remind you of anyone?Strip away the French, the programs, and the green tint, and the Merovingian is exactly like Jeffrey Epstein , the disgraced paedophile who appears to have been friends with every single individual of note in the WENA elite circle.The Merovingianâ€™s lines could very well be Epsteinâ€™s guiding philosophies. The Merovingianâ€™s worldview was transactional and cynical: â€œYou see, there is only one constantâ€¦ causality. Action. Reaction. Cause and effect.â€Similarly, Epsteinâ€™s entire modus operandi was based on being a connector and facilitator who â€œknows thingsâ€ and can â€œopen doorsâ€. The Frenchman also loved mocking the illusion of choice, which he claimed was between those with power and those without. Morality was a theatre for the poor. Both used different forms of hedonism â€” food, sex, language, aesthetics and more â€” as means of demonstrating control without force.Both archetypes posed resistance as futile, believing that the system would favour them forever. The Merovingianâ€™s philosophy of causality mirrors this worldview perfectly. He rejects choice, mocks morality, and insists that all behaviour is simply a response to desire. Control the appetite, and you control the outcome.Epsteinâ€™s system operated on the same premise. He targeted vulnerability, ambition, fear and greed, reducing human agency to transaction. He controlled the most powerful people in the world, coerced them not through force but a degree of perverseness far beyond the realms of polite culture. Epstein did not need force because the system had already mastered what Manufacturing Consent described decades ago, a logic made only more unsettling by the fact that Noam Chomsky himself was someone Epstein was pally with.What makes the parallel even more chilling is how both figures overestimate their own permanence. The Merovingian boasts that he has survived every previous One and will survive Neo as well.Epstein behaved as if his insulation was eternal, as if his proximity to power made him untouchable. But intermediaries are only valuable until they are not. Once their utility fades (or their deeds become known) the system discards them without sentiment.When we meet the Merovingian again decades later (in The Matrix Resurrections), he is reduced to a ranting relic, stripped of relevance, furious not because he has lost morality, but because he has lost access. Epsteinâ€™s collapse follows the same structural logic. The moment the cost of protecting him outweighed the benefit, the network withdrew its shield.When The Matrix first came out, it was heralded as era-defining science fiction.Little did we know it was a foreshadowing of our lives, where we would all become so jacked into our devices that we would forget our real lives, where our every action would be judged by an algorithm tweak, where we would use small machines to peer into the lives of others instead of living our own. And that we would willingly submit ourselves, like Aldous Huxley predicted, not because of oppression but because of convenience.The real deus ex machina was never the machines with tentacles. It was the invisible architecture that learned how to manage human longing itself. And little did we know that the entire operating system was being run by a few men who could control each otherâ€™s guilt.
Article Summary: The Matrix and its sequels (barring the unwatchable The Matrix Resurrections) has had a cultural impact hitherto unseen. Red pill and blue pill became the choice between a hard truth and a comfortable illusion. Waking up meant realising we are surrounded by an illusion.

Article Title: Pakistan sees 361 combat-related deaths in Jan; up 43% from Dec 2025: Think tank

Article Title: Herof 2.0 explained: Balochistan is exploding again
Article Text:

Balochistan Crisis: Pakistan-Origin Commentator Takes Apart Islamabad, Exposes Lies On India

What is clear: the scale, coordination and symbolism of the violence mark a sharp escalation in a conflict long treated by Islamabad as containable.

Between the lines

Whatâ€™s next

The bottom line





Pakistan's latest surge of violence in Balochistan reflects a deepening, not isolated, security crisis as the Baloch Liberation Army escalates its campaign through "Operation Herof."Over several days, the Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) unleashed what it calls "Operation Herof, Phase 2.0," a wave of coordinated attacks across Balochistan that included suicide bombings, gun assaults and arson in major towns and remote districts alike.Pakistani authorities say dozens of civilians and security personnel were killed, followed by one of the largest counterterrorism strikes in decades. Officials claim more than 130 militants were killed in 48 hours alone. However, the BLA has refuted these official claims and reiterate that it inflicted severe casualties on Pakistan forces.Balochistan sits at the intersection of Pakistanâ€™s security, economy and foreign policy- and all three are now under strain. The province anchors Chinaâ€™s Belt and Road ambitions through the port of Gwadar, hosts globally significant mineral deposits at Reko Diq, and borders both Iran and Afghanistan at a time of regional instability.As analyst Michael Kugelman put it after the attacks, "Todayâ€™s attacks in Balochistan should serve as a wake up call to thoseâ€¦ keen to invest in Pakistanâ€™s critical mineral reserves." He warned that many of those reserves lie in areas now directly hit by violence- and that resentment over "external exploitation of local resources" is central to the insurgency.For Islamabad, the stakes go beyond security. Investor confidence, relations with Beijing, and Pakistanâ€™s credibility as a destination for critical minerals are all on the line.Balochistan's troubles are hardly new, but they're shiftingSince Pakistan's birth, Baloch ethnic factions have, time and again, risen up against the central government. They've sought more autonomy, a larger share of the country's wealth, or even complete independence. Each insurrection has been met with military force, temporary quiet, and, ultimately, unaddressed issues.First, economic importance. Balochistan is now crucial to Pakistan's economic story. Think of the Chinese-funded projects and the West's interest in copper, gold, and rare minerals.Second, political disillusionment. Elections since 2018 have been widely criticized, and the space for peaceful opposition has shrunk. This has intensified the feeling that political solutions are impossible.Third, the evolution of militant groups. Organizations like the BLA have become more dangerous, adept at using the media, and ideologically focused. They've adopted tactics from global insurgencies while staying rooted in local grievances.As per a report in the Native Voices: "Herof is a Balochi literary term meaning "black storm", commonly used in Baloch poetry, including by the veteran poet Karim Dashti."The BLA first used the term in August 2024, launching Herof 1.0 with attacks across 12 districts. That campaign shocked authorities by striking areas previously considered relatively stable, including Lasbela and Musakhel, and by introducing a female suicide bomber into the groupâ€™s operations.An intelligence officer cited by Native Voices estimated 800 to 1,000 fighters may be involved- a number that suggests months of recruitment, training and coordination.Pakistani officials describe the violence as foreign-orchestrated terrorism.Balochistan chief minister Sarfraz Bugti said security forces killed 145 members of what he termed "Fitna al-Hindustan," the stateâ€™s label for the BLA. He claimed militants aimed to seize hostages and storm government installations, and alleged backing from India and Afghanistan- accusations both countries deny.Residents recount chaos and fear. "(It) was a very scary day in the history of Quetta," said Khan Muhammad, a local resident, describing armed men openly patrolling streets before security forces moved in.Indiaâ€™s foreign ministry rejected Pakistanâ€™s claims, calling them "baseless," and urged Islamabad to address "long-standing demands of its people in the region" instead of deflecting blame outward.As per the Native Voices, the Baloch resentment has roots in a series of flashpoints.Several incidents hardened public anger: the killing of university student Hayat Baloch by paramilitary forces in 2020; the death of Malik Naz inside her home the same year; the crackdown on the Haq Do Tehreek protests in Gwadar; and the custodial killing of Baalach Mula Baksh in 2023. Each episode sparked protests. Each was followed by arrests, internet shutdowns, or worse.The arrest of activist Dr Mahrang Baloch in 2025 marked another turning point. To many young Baloch, her detention signaled that even peaceful dissent had become intolerable. Analysts say that belief has fed recruitment into armed groups, including among women, a shift now visible on the battlefield.Each episode narrowed political space- and widened the insurgencyâ€™s recruitment pool.As Kugelman noted, framing the crisis solely around body counts "telegraphs your policy failures- because the question is why are there so many fighters to start with." Analysts argue the BLA has successfully tapped into accumulated resentment, especially among young Baloch who see peaceful activism punished and armed resistance rewarded with attention.One of the most striking elements of Herof II has been its media choreography.As per the Native Voices, the BLA released new footage of its leader Bashir Zaib, seated on the back of a motorcycle, moving through rugged terrain believed to lie between Kharan and Chagai- a region synonymous with mineral wealth.Observers see layered symbolism: mobility, control and defiance. A senior Baloch journalist described the location choice as deliberate- close to Reko Diq and other high-profile mining sites that have drawn interest from companies like Barrick Gold and financiers such as the Asian Development Bank.The subtext to Islamabad and investors alike: the insurgency can operate where Pakistanâ€™s economic future is being planned.Timing matters.Analysts believe the BLA launched Herof II amid unrest in neighboring Iranâ€™s Baloch-populated regions and persistent instability in Afghanistan to amplify its message beyond Pakistanâ€™s borders.Balochistanâ€™s long frontier with Iran- and proximity to Gulf shipping lanes- means sustained violence here resonates in Middle Eastern, US and European policy circles, particularly as Western governments search for alternatives to Chinese-dominated mineral supply chains.The message appears aimed as much at foreign capitals as at Islamabad.In the short term, security operations will intensify. Expect heavier troop deployments, stricter controls around mining projects, transport corridors and Chinese-linked infrastructure, and continued information blackouts during operations. Islamabad will likely double down on its claims of foreign sponsorship, even as evidence remains contested.The longer-term trajectory is murkier.The paradox facing Pakistan is stark: Balochistan is now too economically important to ignore- but remains too politically neglected to stabilize.Unless that gap is addressed, the "black storm" the BLA invokes may only deepen, reshaping the conflict from a peripheral insurgency into a central challenge to the state.The spy-action film Dhurandhar has inadvertently revived global interest in the region by featuring elements that touch on Pakistanâ€™s underworld and geopolitics set around Baloch communities.Dhurandhar revolves around a simple but unsettling idea: in covert conflict, what matters most is not the spectacle of action but the slow, almost invisible shifts beneath it. That logic offers a useful lens for whatâ€™s happening in Balochistan.Today, Balochistan can no longer be treated only as a security issue measured through attacks and casualties. It has become a political problem rooted in governance, representation, and legitimacy, and it cannot be managed through messaging, denial, or communication blackouts.
Article Summary: Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) unleashed what it calls "Operation Herof, Phase 2.0," a wave of coordinated attacks across Balochistan that included suicide bombings, gun assaults and arson in major towns and remote districts alike.
